graphicslib3D

Class Vector3D

  • java.lang.Object
    • graphicslib3D.Vector3D
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class Vector3D
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable
    Defines a three-dimensional vector. Each Vector3D object contains four components: X, Y, and Z, the 3-dimensional direction components of the vector, and W, the homogeneous component. Constructors for Vector3D objects always set the homogeneous component of the new vector to zero unles specifically stated otherwise.
    Version:
    4.10 02/18/05
    Author:
    William Dimaculangan, Monika Jankun-Kelly, John Clevenger
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Vector3D()
      Creates a new Vector3D with defaults of X,Y,Z = 1.0 and W = 0.0.
      Vector3D(double x, double y, double z)
      Creates a new Vector3D with the specified x,y,z values; that is, a vector from the origin to (x,y,x).
      Vector3D(double x, double y, double z, double w)
      Creates a new Vector3D with the specified x,y,z, and w values; that is, a vector from the origin to (x,y,z) and containing the specified w component.
      Vector3D(Point3D aPoint)
      Creates a new Vector3D implied by the X,Y,Z values of the specified Point3D; that is, a vector from the origin to the specified point.
      Vector3D(Vertex3D aVertex)
      Creates a new Vector3D implied by the location of the specified Vertex3D; that is, a vector from the origin to the specified vertex's location.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Vector3D

        public Vector3D()
        Creates a new Vector3D with defaults of X,Y,Z = 1.0 and W = 0.0.

      • Vector3D

        public Vector3D(double x,
                double y,
                double z)
        Creates a new Vector3D with the specified x,y,z values; that is, a vector from the origin to (x,y,x). The W component of the new Vector3D is the same as the W value assigned by the Vector3D no-argument constructor.

      • Vector3D

        public Vector3D(double x,
                double y,
                double z,
                double w)
        Creates a new Vector3D with the specified x,y,z, and w values; that is, a vector from the origin to (x,y,z) and containing the specified w component.

      • Vector3D

        public Vector3D(Point3D aPoint)
        Creates a new Vector3D implied by the X,Y,Z values of the specified Point3D; that is, a vector from the origin to the specified point. The W component of the new Vector3D is the same as the W value assigned by the Vector3D no-argument constructor.

      • Vector3D

        public Vector3D(Vertex3D aVertex)
        Creates a new Vector3D implied by the location of the specified Vertex3D; that is, a vector from the origin to the specified vertex's location. The W component of the new Vector3D is the same as the W value assigned by the Vector3D no-argument constructor.

    • Method Detail

      • getX

        public double getX()
        Returns the X component of this Vector3D object.

      • getY

        public double getY()
        Returns the Y component of this Vector3D object.

      • getZ

        public double getZ()
        Returns the Z component of this Vector3D object.

      • getW

        public double getW()
        Returns the W component of this Vector3D object. W is is another name for the homogeneous component.

      • setX

        public void setX(double newX)
        Sets the X component of this Vector3D object.

      • setY

        public void setY(double newY)
        Sets the Y component of this Vector3D object.

      • setZ

        public void setZ(double newZ)
        Sets the Z component of this Vector3D object.

      • setW

        public void setW(double newW)
        Sets the W component of this Vector3D object.

      • clone

        public java.lang.Object clone()
        Returns a new Vector3D which is a deep clone of this Vector3D.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Vector3D other)
        Returns true if all four elements of this Vector3D are equal to the corresponding elements of the specicified Vector3D; false if one or more elements are not the same.

      • minus

        public Vector3D minus(Vector3D v2)
        Returns a new Vector3D whose X,Y,Z values are the difference between this Vector's X,Y,Z and the specified Vector's X,Y,Z. The W component of the new Vector3D is the same as the W value assigned by the Vector3D no-argument constructor.

      • add

        public Vector3D add(Vector3D v2)
        Returns a new Vector3D whose X,Y,Z values are the sum of this Vector's values and the specified Vector's values. The W component of the new Vector3D is the same as the W value assigned by the Vector3D no-argument constructor.

      • mult

        public Vector3D mult(double theMultiplier)
        Returns a new Vector3D which is the result of multiplying this vector by the specified multiplier; that is, a scaled copy of this vector. The W component of the returned vector is not affected (that is, it is the same as the W component of this vector).

      • div

        public Vector3D div(double theDivisor)
        Returns a new Vector3D which is the result of dividing this vector by the specified divisor; that is, a scaled copy of this vector. The W component of the returned vector is not affected (that is, it is the same as the W component of this vector).

      • magnitude

        public double magnitude()
        Returns the magnitude (length) of this vector.

      • normalize

        public Vector3D normalize()
        Returns a new Vector3D with the same direction as this vector but with a length of 1.

      • mult

        public Vector3D mult(Matrix3D mat)
        Returns a new Vector3D which is the result of multiplying this Vector by the given matrix. The order of multiplication is exactly the same as that defined by method Point3D.mult(Matrix3D). The multiplication is performed with the Vector3D "on the right". That is, this method returns a new vector V' such that V' = [givenMatrix] x [thisVector].

      • scale

        public void scale(double scaleFactor)
        Scales each of the X, Y, and Z components of this Vector by the given scaleFactor. Note that unlike most Vector3D methods, this method does NOT return a new Vector3D; it scales THIS Vector. The W value in the Vector is unchanged.

      • dot

        public double dot(Vector3D v)
        Returns the value of the "dot product" of this Vector with and the specified vector. Note that the dot product of two vectors is by definition a scalar value; this method returns that scalar as a double. Only the X, Y, and Z values of the Vectors are used in computing the returned value; the W component is ignored.

      • cross

        public Vector3D cross(Vector3D v)
        Returns a new Vector3D which is the cross product of this vector with the specified vector. Only the X, Y, and Z values of the vectors are used in computing the returned value; the W component of the returned Vector is the default (0.0).

      • interpolate

        public void interpolate(Vector3D finalVec,
                        float changeAmnt)
        Sets this Vector3D to the interpolation by changeAmnt from this to the the specified finalVec; that is, changes the values in this Vector3D as follows:

        this=(1-changeAmnt)*this + (changeAmnt * finalVec)

        Only the X, Y, and Z components of this Vector3D are changed; the W component is not affected.

        Parameters:
        finalVec - The final vector to interpolate towards
        changeAmnt - An amount between 0.0 - 1.0 representing a precentage change from this towards finalVec

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a printable representation of this Vector3D.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
